meta.title: Lines and Angles - Exercise 6.1 (Multiple Choice Questions)

questions.question: In Fig. 6.1, if $AB \parallel CD \parallel EF$, $PQ \parallel RS$, $\angle RQD = 25^\circ$ and $\angle CQP = 60^\circ$, then $\angle QRS$ is equal to
questions.solution:
Given $PQ \parallel RS$. Produce $PQ$ to intersect $CD$ at $M$.
Then $\angle CQP = \angle MQD = 60^\circ$ (Vertically opposite angles).
In $\triangle MQR$, exterior $\angle ARS$ (at $R$ for line $EF$) is related to interior angles.
Alternatively, since $AB \parallel CD \parallel EF$, and $PQ \parallel RS$:
$\angle PQC = 180^\circ - 60^\circ = 120^\circ$.
$\angle ARQ = \angle RQD = 25^\circ$ (Alternate interior angles).
$\angle ARS = 180^\circ - \angle CQP = 120^\circ$ (Corresponding angles logic with parallel transversals).
$\angle QRS = \angle ARQ + \angle ARS = 25^\circ + 120^\circ = 145^\circ$.

questions.question: If one angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the other two angles, then the triangle is
questions.solution:
Let the angles be $\angle A, \angle B, \angle C$.
Given $\angle A = \angle B + \angle C$.
We know $\angle A + \angle B + \angle C = 180^\circ$.
Substituting $\angle B + \angle C = \angle A$, we get $\angle A + \angle A = 180^\circ \Rightarrow 2\angle A = 180^\circ \Rightarrow \angle A = 90^\circ$.
Since one angle is $90^\circ$, the triangle is a right triangle.

questions.question: An exterior angle of a triangle is $105^\circ$ and its two interior opposite angles are equal. Each of these equal angles is
questions.solution:
Let the two equal interior opposite angles be $x$.
Exterior angle = Sum of interior opposite angles.
$105^\circ = x + x \Rightarrow 2x = 105^\circ \Rightarrow x = 52.5^\circ$.

questions.question: The angles of a triangle are in the ratio $5 : 3 : 7$. The triangle is
questions.solution:
Let the angles be $5x, 3x, 7x$.
$5x + 3x + 7x = 180^\circ \Rightarrow 15x = 180^\circ \Rightarrow x = 12^\circ$.
Angles are $5(12)=60^\circ$, $3(12)=36^\circ$, $7(12)=84^\circ$.
Since all angles are less than $90^\circ$, it is an acute angled triangle.

questions.question: If one of the angles of a triangle is $130^\circ$, then the angle between the bisectors of the other two angles can be
questions.solution:
Let the triangle be $ABC$ with $\angle A = 130^\circ$.
The angle between the bisectors of $\angle B$ and $\angle C$ is given by $90^\circ + \frac{1}{2}\angle A$.
Angle $= 90^\circ + \frac{130^\circ}{2} = 90^\circ + 65^\circ = 155^\circ$.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.2, $POQ$ is a line. The value of $x$ is
questions.solution:
Since $POQ$ is a line, the sum of angles on it is $180^\circ$.
$40^\circ + 4x + 3x = 180^\circ$
$7x = 140^\circ$
$x = 20^\circ$.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.3, if $OP \parallel RS$, $\angle OPQ = 110^\circ$ and $\angle QRS = 130^\circ$, then $\angle PQR$ is equal to
questions.solution:
Draw a line through $Q$ parallel to $OP$ (and $RS$).
Let this line be $QM$.
Since $OP \parallel QM$, consecutive interior angles sum to $180^\circ$.
$\angle PQM = 180^\circ - 110^\circ = 70^\circ$.
Since $RS \parallel QM$, consecutive interior angles sum to $180^\circ$.
$\angle RQM = 180^\circ - 130^\circ = 50^\circ$.
$\angle PQR = \angle PQM - \angle RQM = 70^\circ - 50^\circ = 20^\circ$? No, from the figure configuration, usually $\angle PQR = \angle PQM + \angle RQM$ or difference.
If we assume the standard zigzag shape where angles are on opposite sides:
$\angle PQR = 110^\circ + 130^\circ - 180^\circ = 60^\circ$.

questions.question: Angles of a triangle are in the ratio $2 : 4 : 3$. The smallest angle of the triangle is
questions.solution:
Let the angles be $2x, 4x, 3x$.
$2x + 4x + 3x = 180^\circ \Rightarrow 9x = 180^\circ \Rightarrow x = 20^\circ$.
The angles are $40^\circ, 80^\circ, 60^\circ$.
The smallest angle is $40^\circ$.
